title: 106_hr605
content: The "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the Court to prescribe rules and regulations under Section 7254 of title 38, United States Code. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for the recall of retired judges. The "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the recall of retired judges for further service on the Court in accordance with specific criteria outlined in the Act. The "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows recall-eligible retired judges to be recalled for up to 90 days (or the equivalent) at a time, not exceeding 180 days (or the equivalent) in a calendar year, upon certification by the chief judge. If a recalled judge declines to serve (except due to disability), the chief judge must remove them from the recall list. A recall-eligible retired judge can be removed from recall status if they are unable to perform the service due to reasons other than disability. If a retired judge becomes permanently disabled and unable to serve further, they will also be removed from recall status. A recalled judge has the same powers and duties as an active judge. The pay for a recall-eligible retired judge varies depending on their retirement status. Under section 7253(e) of this title, a recalled judge who retired under chapter 83 or 84 of title 5 will be considered a reemployed annuitant. This does not affect the right of a retired judge to serve as a reemployed annuitant under title 5. SEC. 4 amends Section 7296(b) of title 38, United States Code, to only credit years of service as a judge of the Court for calculating an individual's years of service. Any fractional part of a year less than 183 days will be disregarded, while 183 days or more will be credited as a full year. SEC. 5 addresses judges' retired pay. SEC. 4 amends Section 7296(b) of title 38, United States Code, to credit years of service as a judge of the Court for calculating an individual's years of service. Any fractional part of a year less than 183 days will be disregarded, while 183 days or more will be credited as a full year. SEC. 5 addresses judges' retired pay, specifying different rates based on recall eligibility and notice of availability for service in a recalled status. The retired pay of a judge under section 7257 shall be the pay at the time of removal from recall status. Cost-of-living adjustments apply to retired pay only in certain cases, ensuring retired chief judges' pay does not exceed the annual rate of pay for the chief judge of the court. Cost-of-living adjustments for retired judges ensure their pay does not exceed the annual rate of pay for judges of the court. Military retired pay for judges is suspended during active service on the court but resumes upon retirement. SEC. 6. LIMITATION ON ACTIVITIES OF RETIRED JUDGES. Retired judges forfeit pay if representing clients on veterans' benefits claims. SEC. 7. EARLY RETIREMENT AUTHORITY FOR CURRENT JUDGES TO STAGGER TERMS. Retirement Authorized - One eligible judge may retire each year from 1999 to 2003. Eligible Judges must meet specific criteria including years of service and age. If multiple judges qualify, the most senior judge can retire. Notice must be given to retire in a specific year. An eligible judge can retire each year from 1999 to 2003 by providing written notice to the President and chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims by April 1 of that year. The retirement date will be during the fiscal year in which notice is given, not earlier than 90 days after providing notice. In 1999, judges can retire between 90 to 120 days after providing notice. Retired judges are considered under section 7296(b)(1) of title 38, United States Code. The rate of retired pay is calculated based on years of service and age. Adjustments in retired pay for judges available for recall are subject to section 7296(f)(3)(B) of title 38, United States Code. Adjustments in retired pay for judges available for recall are subject to section 7296(f)(3)(B) of title 38, United States Code. The denominator is 80. An adjustment in annuities under civil service retirement laws applies to retired pay for recall-eligible judges. The term 'present value' includes a value determined by an actuary for payments from the retirement fund.
